title: Can we all agree the ryze doesn't deserve a shield?
body:
His damage is literally the easiest thing to apply in the world. His cooldowns are non-existant. Stormraider is completely broken on him.

His scaling is crazy. He doesn't deserve a shield in his kit. He is one of the most oppressive mages in the game. Swain is easier to kill then him but he does 3x more damage.

replies.body: The speed buff should be enough specially because his build tends to be on the more defensive side of things.

A speed buff is not enough when you need to be in the frontliner's range to deal damage to them. The trade off for range is usually survivability, either in the form of blinks/dashes, invulnerability or tankyeness. So unless Ryze is getting some form of blink or dodge, I highly doubt that removing his shield would be a good idea.

Anivia and Aurelion both have crowd control and different ways of keeping you where they want you to be. Karthus is the only exception to that but that is because his passive allows him to continue casting and using spells + you probably don't want to hug him for too long anyway. 

Ryze only has a 1 second CC that can be increased to 2 seconds if he wants to lose some DPS in favor of surviving better. 

But do you know the difference? Snares are soft cc. They do not hinder your ability to deal damage yourself, unless your spell is based on movement. His low range also means that anybody that isn't a melee champ (and even they have spells they can use) can retaliate. If you get stunned by Anivia you'll lose 80% of your HP unless you're a tank. If you get stunned by Aurelion, you're gonna die. If Ryze snares you, you can fight back. He needs a second or third rotation to get a kill, other mages kill in one.

Yup Ryze is totally easy to play and is effective at elos below masters.

Uh, if you actually looked at data you provided you'd realize that he's totally bonkers.

His Playerbase Average Games Played is 21 on mid and 31 on top - that means he has a lot of newbie players that obviously are not that effective with him (they probably try him out and get discouraged, because he does take some skill).

Then, you look at the people that actually play him a lot (over 50 games):
>Mid
50 games+: 52% winrate
125 games+: 61% winrate

>Top
50 games+: 58% winrate
125 games+: 76% winrate

I do realize that those are still kinda inflated, but that's a VERY impressive winrate regardless.

Let's be fair, a 2% playrate with only 2% of the previous 2% being over 125 games means that this is going to be based on an EXTREMELY small sample size. It is not kinda inflated, it is VERY inflated. Specially because we're taking into consideration only plat+, which is about the top 5% of the playerbase.

Well, compare it to similar playrate champs and Ryze is still looking very strong. As far as Plat+ goes, I believe this is about the spot where Rito should focus on balance, so that's okay.

The other one that's very worrying is Ivern actually.

Players with 125+ games Ivern have 99,47% winrate. If it was 100% winrate, that'd be no problem (low sample size, every game won), but since it's 99,47% that means Ivern players with over 125 games have at least 187 wins and 1 lose (possibly more in the same ratio W:L). The rest of his stats are also mind-boggling (53% average winrate with 12 games played on average)

Wait what? This Ivern winrate makes me think that there might be some problems with champion.gg algorithm, or, at the very least, an error when reading data.

A 99.47% winrate indicates that not only they have 187:1 winratio, but that they are immune to enemies snowballs, feeders, disconections or any other things that are out of their control. Which is very unlikely.

My guess is that it is 100%, but that the champion gg algorithm cannot produce a 100% number (for whatever reason). So it instead gives the highest possible number within whatever system set it has. A limitation that **normally** is irrelevant.

I may be wrong, I don't have a clue and am making a guess.

I know it was 100% some time ago (and that's when I discarded it as just small sample size), so it kinda hints that it works?

Dunno, but I also think it's very unlikely.

No, we can't all agree. These things are made for a reason (Yasuo windwall+passive, Ryze shield + ms when overloading, Vayne max hp true damage, Rivens mobility, the list goes on). Once you start taking away parts of a champion, you actually make it harder to balance them and remove what makes them unique. Ryze is balanced with his shield + ms in mind, you take that away and you have to buff him in other areas (which, speaking as a Ryze main, you really don't want :P). Perhaps his numbers could be tuned sure, but thats all he needs. He is a very high skill-cap champion and it takes hours of practice for the Ryze player to get to the point where he becomes difficult to deal with for the enemy team, but thats the reward for spending hours learning him and taking the risk every game that you could easily fuck something up by just missing a Q (not something a champion, say, Kayle has. ((who is arguably stupid broken))). 

I'm not saying Ryze should be OP when you've played 200 games with him, all things have to come with a balance cap, but thankfully thats what Rito has done. He becomes a problem late game because he scales with mana and can easily get over 1000 ap. He has no CD's because anyone sensible playing Ryze will take scaling CDR runes (and runes need a big overhaul anyway) and build 30% CDR very early (Ionian boots + Morello. He also has his resets which are staple for a combo-based champion). CDR is an overly accessible stat also, but we all know Items are a difficult thing to deal with for Riot.  Early game however, the only thing he has is his root (which is a staple in Ryzes kit, he literally wouldn't work without it) and his shield+ms. He needs these things to survive, otherwise he wouldn't be a fun champ to play, and you end up with yet another dead champion.

If you're struggling to deal with Ryze, don't get mad because he ran away with 100 health. Instead, improve yourself, play him like, 10 games and you'll see his glaring weaknesses. Game knowledge > Everything.
Also the smart Ryze player will take Thunderlords, not Stormraiders. If you went against a Ryze that took storm, you were either against a bad Ryze, or an extremely cocky Ryze.
